sections.text: In this article we present CASP solutions for dealing with PDDL + problems, i.e. encoding PDDL + to CASP, and enhancements to the algorithm of the ezcsp CASP Solver for solving CASP programs arising from PDDL + domains. An experimental analysis carried out on known linear and non-linear variants of PDDL + domains, involving different configurations of the ezcsp Solver, other CASP Solvers and PDDL + Planners, shows the feasibility of our solution.

sections.heading: 3.2 Encoding
sections.text: This section is dedicated to discussing our coding of PDDL + problems in CASP. Our approach is based on research into actions and changes and language of action (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1993; Reiter 2001; Chintabathina et al. 2005). It builds on the existing SAT-based (Kautz and Selman 1992) and ASP-based planning approaches and extends them to hybrid areas. Considering actions and changes, the development of a domain over time is often represented by a transition diagram (or transition system) that represents states and transitions between states by actions. Traditionally, actions in transition diagrams are instantaneous, and states have no duration and are described by sets of Boolean flows. Sequences of states that characterize domain developments are presented as a sequence of discrete time steps determined by integral numbers, so that step 0 corresponds to the original state in sequence.

Specifically, we will consider a variant of the architecture of Section 5 that aims to make better use of the information provided by VAL to find a plan that is not valid, it will return information about which invariants have been violated and at what time intervals. Let us consider a variant of instance 1 of the non-linear generators from Section 5, modified so that the capacity and output level of the generator are 100 units.

sections.heading: 7 Related Work
sections.text: In this section, we analyze related approaches and hybrid automats to handle hybrid systems. We start with PDDL +, then move on to CASP. Lastly, we refer to our approach to research on planning in hybrid domains based on action languages; however, PDDL + algorithms and solutions are unable to handle hybrid domains (Penberthy and Weld 1994; McDermott 2003; Li and Williams 2008; Coles et al. 2012; Shin and Davis 2005). However, none of these approaches is able to handle the full set of PDDL + features, namely non-linear domains with processes and events. Recent work includes (Bryce et al. 2015) presenting an approach based on handling hybrid domains. However, dReach does not use PDDL + features, and cannot handle exogenous events.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: PDDL + and CASP languages extend PDDL and ASP to reason with mixed discrete-continuous dynamics. PDDL + is the default language for the automated planning community, with a number of interesting areas presented as PDDL + models. In this paper, we have presented a new approach to solving PDDL + problems by encoding in CASP problems and extending the ezcsp solution architecture for planning in hybrid domains. Our solution can handle both linear and non-linear variants of domains. An experimental analysis conducted on known PDDL + domains, with some variants of our approach, other CASP solvers and PDDL + planners involved in two argumentation tasks, demonstrated the feasibility of our approach.

metadata.abstractText: CASP is an extension of ASP that allows for numerical constraints to be added in the rules. PDDL+ is an extension of the PDDL standard language of automated planning for modeling mixed discrete-continuous dynamics. In this paper, we present CASP solutions for dealing with PDDL+ problems, i.e., encoding from PDDL+ to CASP, and extensions to the algorithm of the ezcsp CASP solver in order to solve CASP programs arising from PDDL+ domains. An experimental analysis, performed on well-known linear and non-linear variants of PDDL+ domains, involving various configurations of the ezcsp solver, other CASP solvers, and PDDL+ planners, shows the viability of our solution. Under consideration in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP).
